conclusion: Determine temperature at state B using p-V diagram and ideal gas law.
Variables: P (pressure), V (volume), n (moles), R (ideal gas constant), T (temperature).
Gas returns to initial state; n and R are constant.
State A: P_A = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 2 L.
State B: P_B = 4 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 2 L.
State C: P_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 5 L.
Apply ideal gas law at State A: P_A V_A = nRT_A.
Equation at State A: (1 x 10^5 Pa) x (2 L) = nR x 200 K.
Apply ideal gas law at State B: P_B V_B = nRT_B.
Equation at State B: (4 x 10^5 Pa) x (2 L) = nRT_B.
Relate State A and B using constant nR: P_A V_A / T_A = P_B V_B / T_B.
Substitute known values: (1 x 10^5 Pa) x (2 L) / 200 K = (4 x 10^5 Pa) x (2 L) / T_B.
Solve for T_B: 2 x 10^5 / 200 = 8 x 10^5 / T_B.
Calculate T_B: T_B = 8 x 10^5 x 200 / 2 x 10^5.
Final answer: Temperature at state B is 800 K.
